title: What's Jimi Hendrix's best album? - Quora

response.answer_text: The only reason I don’t just say Electric Ladyland, and leave it at that, is because that album is not the best place to start if you are just getting into Jimi. Electric Ladyland is typically the favorite album of people that have already gotten deeply into Are you Experienced? and/or Axis. Actually if you haven’t listened to them, at a cursory glance, you might think that those first two albums are stronger on a track-by-track basis. You wouldn’t be wrong either, every song on the first two albums are gems, rock classics in every sense of the word. The albums are also sequenced in a very straightforward rock album way also. Very radio-friendly. Every track on Electric Ladyland is also a gem, however the sequence is much less user-friendly, and harder to take in if you are not already a fan of the first two albums. The two tracks that are perhaps considered to be the most epic to fans are Voodoo Chile (last track of side 1) and 1983. The former track is raw blues with a pickup band (including Jack Casady and Steve Winwood), recorded late night in the studio, one-take no overdubs. One of the best live in the studio tracks I’ve ever heard from any band, ever. I still get chills listening to this so many years later, even though I know pretty much every note and nuance of this performance. 1983 is hard to describe as a track, and even harder, without the context of his other work, and of the year 1968 in general. To me, this is the most full exploration of Jimi’s talents of songwriting and studio wizardry, all the while exploring the depths of his psyche and creativity. I love every track on this album, but over the years I have come to think of it as 4 extraordinary EPs that hold up fantastically as a single album, but that are too difficult to fully take in during a single listening session. So yes, start with the first two albums and enjoy them in the light of some of the best rock albums ever created, take a pause and spend a week of your life getting into Electric Ladyland. One thing I will guarantee, comparing him to another guitarist will drop from your radar, and fast. Also, as to his later albums. I love some of them, but with the except of Band of Gypsies , they are all posthumous, and very few of the tracks were completed to Jimi’s standards. Band of Gypsies is also great, and essential to a fan, but flawed enough to make it not such a great place to start.

The executive summary: arguably the best album in rock history (the American version) … and one that changed my life as much as “Meet The Beatles” (side one) … is … Are You Experienced … his first album, released May 1967. Is it actually possible for an album to consist of ALL great songs? This one does IMO. Going through song by song … I have to start at the end, with the last track … “Are You Experienced” … arguably the greatest song in rock history (it’s my personal favorite … maybe I’ll ask for it to be played at my funeral lol) , the most pioneering (with, say, the Beatles’ “Strawberry Fields Forever” and “A Day in the Life”) … as great an ending song as “A Day in the Life” certainly, which are IMO the two best endings ever, along with the last minute of The Beatles’ “The End” (… “and, in the end ….”) Back to Side One, track by track … “Purple Haze” … Are you kidding me? How good can a rock song be? It’s been killed by over-covering by party bands because it’s a simple song, but still … “Manic Depression” … see my comment on “Purple Haze” “Hey Joe” … my own high school/party band covered Jimi’s slow, killer, version of this, with me playing the lead on an electric violin … but I digress. Once again, how damn good can a cover version of someone else’s song be? Only cover-song that’s close IMO: Beatles’/Lennon’s “Twist and Shout” “Love or Confusion:” underrated song … hey, check out my good friend (from the old days, traipsing the ashrams of northern India together) Eric Johnson’s cover of it:  “May This Be Love:” Magical, mystical track … foreshadows those great, sad tracks on “Axis Bold as Love” “I Don’t Live Today:” the finale of Side One is not the greatest track on the album, but they can’t all be - and it’s the ONLY track I’d say that about. Side Two “The Wind Cries Mary” … are you friggin kidding me? Is this the best ballad ever writtten, or just one of the Top Five? “Fire:” see the comment on Purple Haze/Manis Depression ... it’s a trio! “Third Stone from the Sun:” experimental track extraordinarie, ala “Tomorrow Never Knows” from The Beatles’ Revolver album. “Foxy Lady” … are you friggin kidding me? See my comment on “Purple Haze” .. now we have a quad! “Are You Experienced” … heaven.
